hawaiian_text: Noho ihola i laila, mahi ‘ai, ‘elua āna mau māla  ‘uala lō‘ihi e waiho nei ā hiki i kēia lā, a ua kapa ‘ia  ka inoa o ia mau māla, ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o ā hiki i  kēia lā. A o‘o ka ‘uala, ‘ōlelo ‘o Puali‘i i kāna ‘ōlelo   ho‘ohiki, “Aia ā kālua ke po‘o o ka ulua me ka ‘uala,  a ‘ai ‘o Puali‘i, a laila, noa, ‘ai kāna wahine, Pōka‘ī a  me nā mea ‘ē a‘e. No laila, iho akula ‘o Puali‘i i kai  o Honouliuli e lawai‘a i i‘a ‘ai pū me ka ‘uala.
llama4-scout-fireworks_translation: He stayed there for a long time, cultivating food, and his two taro patches of long ‘uala still exist until this day, and the name of those patches was given as Nāmakaokapāo‘o until this day. When the ‘uala was ready, Puali‘i said in his promise, “When the head of the ulua fish and the ‘uala are cooked, Puali‘i will eat, and then his wife, Pōka‘ī, and others can eat. Therefore, Puali‘i went down to the shore of Honouliuli to fish for food to eat with the ‘uala.
llama4-scout-fireworks_commentary:
This passage from Chapter 1, Paragraph 4, provides valuable insights into Hawaiian cultural practices, linguistic features, and historical context.

Culturally, the passage highlights the significance of taro ( ‘uala ) cultivation in traditional Hawaiian society. Taro was a staple crop and a vital source of food, and its cultivation was often associated with spiritual and ceremonial practices. The fact that Puali‘i's taro patches, Nāmakaokapāo‘o, still exist until this day underscores the enduring importance of the land and the cultural heritage.

The passage also showcases the importance of food sharing and reciprocity in Hawaiian culture. Puali‘i's promise to eat with his wife, Pōka‘ī, and others only after he has eaten signifies the cultural value placed on sharing food and ensuring the well-being of family and community members.

Linguistically, the passage features several notable elements. The use of the phrase "noho ihola" (stayed there for a long time) illustrates the Hawaiian concept of time and duration, which is often expressed through verb phrases rather than specific time measurements. The term "māla ‘uala lō‘ihi" (taro patches of long ‘uala) highlights the importance of taro varieties and their classification.

The passage also employs traditional Hawaiian narrative structures, such as the use of sequential clauses ("a o‘o ka ‘uala...") to convey a series of events. The incorporation of direct speech ("‘ōlelo ‘o Puali‘i...") adds to the narrative's authenticity and provides insight into Puali‘i's thoughts and feelings.

Historically, the passage provides a glimpse into the lives of Hawaiians prior to European contact. The mention of specific locations, such as Honouliuli, and the practice of fishing and taro cultivation, suggest a thriving and self-sufficient community. The passage also alludes to the significance of spiritual and ceremonial practices, as evidenced by Puali‘i's promise and the ritualistic connotations of sharing food.

Overall, this passage offers a rich and nuanced exploration of Hawaiian culture, language, and history, highlighting the importance of taro cultivation, food sharing, and community reciprocity in traditional Hawaiian society.

reference_translation: They lived there and farmed, and Puali‘i had two  long sweet potato patches that remain until today,  and the patches were given the name,   Nāmakaokapāo‘o until today. When the sweet  potatoes were mature, Puali‘i said made a  promise, saying, “I’ll cook the head of an ulua fish  in the imu along with some sweet potatoes. When  Puali‘i eats, then the food will be made free for his  woman, Pōka‘ī, and anyone else.” So, Puali‘i went  down to the shore of Honouliuli to fish for a catch  to eat with sweet potatoes.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 4:**• Pua-li‘i is a farmer with 2 long sweet potato patches  that lasted until the publication of this story. The  name of this sweet potato garden was known as *Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o*, the name of Pō-ka-‘ī’s son, and  victorious hero of the story;  • When the sweet potatoes were ready for harvest,  Pua-li‘i said that when he eats ulua fish with sweet  potatoes, cooked in the imu. The food would then be  made free for others, particularly Pō-ka-‘ī and Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o after he eats.  – The emphasis on Pua-li‘i, a male and head of the  family, eating, with his woman and child being  allowed to eat separately after he was done, is a  custom of ‘Ai Kapu culture;  • Having announced the eating routine/schedule, Pua li‘i then went to Hono-uliuli (dark bay) to fish for  ulua.  – The choice of ulua to eat with the ‘uala (sweet  potato) is likely due to the similarity in the   pronunciation of the two words, signifying ʻwhat is  above, so below,’ an old and recurring esoteric  feature of Hawaiian prosidy and culture, with a  lesson that there should always be balance in life  and in human practices (above-below; left-right;  male-female). This is the essence of ʻpono’;
